children.name: stop
children.definition: /stɒpǁstɑːp/  to no longer do something that you had been doing:ngưng, dừng lại
examples: ▪ He wrote quickly, but from time to time he stopped and looked out of the window.

children.name: stop doing something: ngừng làm gì
examples: ▪ I stopped reading and turned out the light.
▪ Please will you all stop making so much noise!

children.name: stop what you are doing: ngừng những gì ai đang làm
examples: ▪ Could you stop what you are doing and pay attention, please?
stop for lunch/coffee/a break etc: nghỉ để ăn trưa/uống cafe/ăn sáng/...
▪ What time do you want to stop for lunch?

children.name: finish
children.definition: /ˈfɪnɪʃ/  to stop doing something because you have completed it:hoàn thành
examples: ▪ She spoke for ten minutes, and when she had finished the audience cheered.
▪ We should have finished the job by next week
.finish doing something: hoàn thành việc gì
▪ Have you finished reading the papers?
▪ After you’ve finished painting the house you can start on the garage.

children.name: quit
children.definition: /kwɪt/  especially American, spoken to stop doing something, especially something that annoys other people: ngưng, kết thúc

children.name: quit doing something: ngưng làm gì
examples: ▪I wish he’d quit bothering me.
▪ They should quit complaining and just get on with their job!

children.name: cease
children.definition: /siːs/  formal to stop doing something:ngưng, nghỉ, thôi không làm
examples: ▪ All conversation ceased as the two police officers entered.
▪ The factory has now ceased production and will close next month.

children.name: cease doing something: ngưng làm gì
examples: ▪ The mill ceased operating commercially two years ago.

children.name: cease to do something: ngừng để làm gì
examples: ▪ Many of these firms have now ceased to exist.

children.name: to stop having a particular type of food or drink
cut out
children.definition: /ˌkʌt ˈaʊt/  to stop eating a particular type of food, especially for health reasons:cắt khẩu phần ăn
examples: ▪ With this diet, I have to cut out bread, cookies, and cakes.
▪ Try cutting out red meat and dairy produce, and see if your symptoms improve.

children.name: lay off
children.definition: /ˌleɪ ˈɒf/  spoken to stop eating, drinking, or using a particular type of food, drink, or drug, especially for health reasons:ngừng làm gì (Vì sức khỏe)
examples: ▪ I’m trying to lay off rich food for a while to lose some weight.
▪ If he really wants to write the book, he’ll need to lay off the drink until he does it.

children.name: what you say when you tell sb to stop doing sth
stop
children.definition: /stɒpǁstɑːp/  spoken:ngưng
examples: ▪ Stop what you’re doing when the buzzer sounds
stop doing something: ngừng làm gì
▪ Will you please stop talking and listen to me!
stop it/that: ngừng lại
▪ Stop it! You’re hurting me.

children.name: quit
children.definition: /kwɪt/  American spoken say this to tell someone to stop doing something because it annoys you:bỏ, dừng lại
examples: quit it/that: dừng lại đi!
▪ Quit that! You’re driving me crazy.
▪ I hated the way she was teasing me. ‘Quit it!’ I said.

children.name: quit doing something: dừng làm gì
examples: ▪ Quit fooling around and pay attention.

children.name: cut it out
children.definition: alsopack it inBritish /ˌkʌt ɪt ˈaʊt, ˌpæk ɪt ˈɪn/  use this to tell someone to stop doing something because it annoys you:ngừng lại!
examples: ▪ Come on, you two, cut it out!
▪ Just cut it out, Jim. Stop acting like a kid.
▪ Oh, pack it in you lot, or we’re going straight home.

children.name: lay off
children.definition: /ˌleɪ ˈɒf/  say this when you want someone to stop doing or saying something that is annoying you:ngừng lại
examples: ▪ Look, I don’t want to argue with you, so just lay off.
▪ Lay off the swearing, if you don’t mind.
▪ Hey, lay off Vinnie, will you? He hasn’t done you any harm.

children.name: to stop working at the end of the day or during the day
stop work
children.definition: /ˌstɒp ˈwɜːʳkǁˌstɑːp-/  British:hết giờ làm việc

children.name: ▪ We stop work at half past three on Fridays.'
examples: ▪ They stopped work for a few minutes to consider his offer.

children.name: finish work
children.definition: /ˌfɪnɪʃ ˈwɜːʳk/  especially British to stop work at the end of the day:hoàn thành việc gì

children.name: ▪ What time do you finish work?finish finish work
examples: ▪ I don’t finish until seven tonight, so I’ll be late home.

children.name: knock off
children.definition: /ˌnɒk ˈɒfǁˌnɑːk-/  spoken to stop work - use this especially to talk about a particular time that you stop work:xong việc
examples: ▪ Is it OK if I knock off a little early tonight?
▪ I usually knock off at about six.

children.name: call it a day
children.definition: /ˌkɔːl ɪt ə ˈdeɪ/  informal to decide to stop working because you have done enough work, because you are very tired, or because it is late:quyết định ngừng làm việc (vì đã làm xong hoặc vì đã trễ)
examples: : ▪ We realized we weren’t going to get the job finished, so we decided to call it a day.
▪ Look, we’re all tired - let’s call it a day.

children.name: pack up
children.definition: /ˌpæk ˈʌp/  British to stop work, put away your work equipment, and go home:làm xong công việc
examples: ▪ Everyone packed up and went home.
▪ OK, guys - it’s time to pack up now.

children.name: to stop doing sth without successfully completing it
give up
children.definition: /ˌgɪv ˈʌp/  to stop trying to do something because it is too difficult or because you are not determined enough:từ bỏ
examples: ▪ I made several attempts to repair the damage, but gave up in the end.
▪ Come on, don’t give up yet!
give up something: từ bỏ việc gì
▪ We will never give up our struggle
give up doing something: từ bỏ làm gì
▪ I’ve given up trying to get her to change her mind.
give something up: từ bỏ làm gì
We did start a protest, but gave it up when we realized we would never be successful.

children.name: quit
children.definition: /kwɪt/  especially American to stop doing something before you have successfully completed it:từ bỏ, ngừng

children.name: ▪ Bill was cold, hungry and tired and he wanted to quit
examples: ▪ She was having a lot of trouble finding a job, but she refused to quit.

children.name: quit doing something: ngừng làm gì
examples: ▪ I knew I’d never be any good at school, so I just quit trying.

children.name: abandon
children.definition: /əˈbændən/  to stop doing something that you had planned or started, because there are too many other problems involved:từ bỏ, bỏ rơi
examples: ▪ The government has now abandoned its plans to privatize parts of the health service.

children.name: ▪ All attempts to find a peaceful solution to the conflict have now been abandoned
examples: .▪ Owing to rough weather, the coast guard had been forced to abandon the search.

children.name: drop
children.definition: /drɒpǁdrɑːp/  to stop doing something that you have already started or that you intended to do:ngừng, hoãn
examples: ▪ Because of strong opposition, the government has dropped plans to increase taxes on fuel.

children.name: drop everything: hoãn lại mọi thứ
examples: ▪ I’m too busy to just drop everything and go out for the day.

children.name: leave it at that
children.definition: /ˌliːv ɪt ət ˈðæt/  informal to stop doing something because you are satisfied that you have done enough:ngừng làm
examples: ▪ We’ve got most of the heavy work done, so I think we can leave it at that for today.

children.name: to stop doing an activity that you used to do regularly
stop
children.definition: /stɒpǁstɑːp/ ngưng, kết thúc
examples: ▪ I used to play a lot of tennis, but I had to stop when I injured my knee.

children.name: stop doing something: ngưng làm gì
examples: ▪ I stopped going to church after I left home.
▪ There’s not much demand for this type of car, so we stopped making them.

children.name: give up
children.definition: /ˌgɪv ˈʌp/  to stop doing something that you used to do regularly, for example because you are no longer physically able to do it:từ bỏ

children.name: give up doing something: từ bỏ việc làm gì
examples: ▪ As he grew older he gave up going for walks and seldom went out.
▪ After the accident she had to give up riding and farming.

children.name: give up something: từ bỏ việc gì
examples: ▪ He gave up his job so that he could look after his wife.

children.name: give something up: từ bỏ việc gì
examples: ▪ I used to really enjoy dancing, but I had to give it up after I became ill.

children.name: drop
children.definition: /drɒpǁdrɑːp/  to stop studying a subject at school, college, or university:bỏ giữa chừng

children.name: ▪ I think I may drop French next year and concentrate on my other languages
examples: .▪ You can drop one subject at the end of this year if you’re finding you’ve got too much work.

children.name: words for describing sth that you are unable to stop doing
compulsive
children.definition: /kəmˈpʌlsɪv/ không thể cưỡng lại
examples: compulsive behaviour/gambling/eating etc : thói quen/thói cờ bạc/thói quen ăn không thể cưỡng lại
something, especially something harmful, that you do because you cannot stop yourself:
▪ Her problem is her compulsive eating.
▪ Compulsive behaviour is often a symptom of deeper psychological problems
a compulsive liar/eater/gambler etc: người nào đó không thể ngừng nói dối/ăn/cờ bạc
someone who is unable to stop lying, eating etc
▪ He’s a compulsive liar -- you can’t believe a word he says.

children.name: to stop a bad or unhealthy habit
stop
children.definition: /stɒpǁstɑːp/ kết thúc, chấm dứt
examples: ▪ She had smoked for nearly twenty years before she finally managed to stop.

children.name: stop doing something: chấm dứt việc làm gì
examples: ▪ The health advice to people is simple - stop eating so much fat and eat more fruit and vegetables.

children.name: quit
children.definition: /kwɪt/  informal to stop doing something that that has been an unhealthy or harmful habit:ngừng, nghỉ
examples: ▪ If you’ve smoked for a long time it can be very difficult to quit.

children.name: quit doing something: ngừng làm gì
examples: ▪ They told me at the hospital to quit drinking for a while.
▪ I quit taking the pills because they were making me put on weight.

children.name: give up
children.definition: /geɪv ʌp/  to stop doing something such as smoking, drinking alcohol, or taking drugs because it is harmful or unhealthy:từ bỏ

children.name: ▪ If you smoke, try to give up or at least cut down
examples: .▪ She gave up drinking over 10 years ago.

children.name: break the habit/kick the habit
children.definition: Break the habit/kick the habit/ˌbreɪk ðə ˈhæbt, ˌkɪk ðə ˈhæbt/  informal to stop doing something that has been a habit for a long time, especially a bad or dangerous habit:từ bỏ thói quen
examples: ▪ The centre provides help for addicts who have kicked their habit and want to stay away from drugs.
▪ Some smokers use hypnosis to help them kick the habit.

children.name: come off
children.definition: /ˌkʌm ˈɒf/  to stop taking medicine or drugs that you have been taking regularly:ngưng dùng thuốc
examples: ▪ The doctor told me I could come off the drugs six months after the operation.
▪ People need help to come off hard drugs like heroin and cocaine.

children.name: grow out of
children.definition: /ˌgrəʊ ˈaʊt ɒv/  if a childgrows outof a habit, he or she stops doing it as they get older:không còn làm nữa
examples: grow out of it: không còn làm điều đó nữa
▪ Wetting the bed is a common problem, but children nearly always grow out of it
▪ He became obsessed with football at the age of four, and he’s never grown out of it!

children.name: throw in the towel
children.definition: throw/chuck in the towel

children.name: to stop trying to do something because you have realized that you cannot succeed
examples: Three of the original five candidates for the Democratic presidential nomination have now thrown in the towel.

children.name: turn your back on
children.definition: turnyourback onsth(alsoturn away fromsth)

children.name: to stop being involved in something
examples: Spain cannot afford to turn its back on tourism.
